Diagrammatic category theory

Kenji Nakahira

Abstract

In category theory, the use of string diagrams is well known to aid in the intuitive understanding of certain concepts, particularly when dealing with adjunctions and monoidal categories. We show that string diagrams are also useful in exploring fundamental properties of basic concepts in category theory, such as universal properties, (co)limits, Kan extensions, and (co)ends. For instance, string diagrams are utilized to represent visually intuitive proofs of the Yoneda lemma, necessary and sufficient conditions for being adjunctions, the fact that right adjoints preserve limits (RAPL), and necessary and sufficient conditions for having pointwise Kan extensions. We also introduce a method for intuitively calculating (co)ends using diagrammatic representations and employ it to prove several properties of (co)ends and weighted (co)limits. This paper proposes that using string diagrams is an effective approach for beginners in category theory to learn the fundamentals of the subject in an intuitive and understandable way.

1 Introduction

String diagrams are commonly used as graphical representations in category theory (e.g., [1, 7, 14, 15]). They serve as a tool for visually depicting concepts such as adjunctions and monoidal categories in an easily understandable way. In recent years, string diagrams have found widespread use in various fields beyond mathematics that apply category theory, including computer science, physics, control theory, and linguistics.
The aim of this paper is to demonstrate the usefulness of string diagrams in learning basic concepts of category theory. Currently, commutative diagrams are predominantly used in standard category theory textbooks, while string diagrams are seldom employed. This paper proposes that using string diagrams is an effective approach for beginners to intuitively grasp the fundamentals of category theory. String diagrams can not only represent concepts intuitively but also aid in proving various statements. For instance, we use string diagrams to prove the Yoneda lemma (see Theorem 3.15), necessary and sufficient conditions for being adjunctions (see Theorems 4.8 and 4.12), the fact that right adjoints preserve limits (RAPL) (see Theorem 5.16), and necessary and sufficient conditions for having pointwise Kan extensions (see Theorem 6.20). We also introduce diagrams for intuitively calculating (co)ends and employ them to demonstrate some relationships between (co)limits, (co)ends, weighted (co)limits, and pointwise Kan extensions. It is well known that, with string diagrams, calculations involving functors and natural transformations can be performed without explicitly considering functoriality or naturality. Additionally, we show that string diagrams are useful for verifying whether given data satisfies functoriality, naturality, universal property, etc.
We explain basic concepts in category theory (specifically, universal property, adjunctions, (co)limits, Kan extensions, (co)ends, etc.) using string diagrams. For more information on these concepts, please refer to sources such as Refs. [6, 11]. Reference [5] is also helpful for (co)end calculations. This paper is largely self-contained; however, we assume that the reader has a basic understanding of the fundamental properties of category theory. The primary objective of this paper is to demonstrate the usefulness of string diagrams; we do not discuss various interesting examples or some basic concepts (e.g., epi- or monomorphisms and examples of (co)limits such as equalizers) where string diagrams may not be particularly helpful. We do not address monoidal categories because the method of representing them with string diagrams has already been extensively studied (e.g., [14] and its references). Our focus is on categories or 2-categories consisting of categories, excluding enriched categories or general bicategories.

1.1 Features of string diagrams

Diagrams commonly employed in standard textbooks can be classified into two types from a certain perspective: (a) those that represent morphisms with arrows and (b) those that consider 2-categories consisting of categories and represent functors with arrows. In what follows, we refer to them as (a) arrow diagrams and (b) pasting diagrams [2, 10]. We here provide several examples of them and briefly describe their relationship with the corresponding string diagrams used in this paper.

(1) Relationship with arrow diagrams

(A) arrow diagram:
(B) string diagram:
This arrow diagram is commutative,which means that the two paths from Fa to Gb ,i.e., Gf∘αa and αb∘Ff ,are equal (where ∘ is the composition of morphisms). Information such as that F and G are functors from C to D is usually not included in arrow diagrams,but it is present in string diagrams. Note that it can also be represented by a string diagram as follows (see in detail in Eq. (2.6)):
As the second example,a universal morphism ⟨u,η⟩ from c∈C to G:D→C is represented by
(A) arrow diagram: (B) string diagram:
(1.1)
In the string diagram,the black circle represents η . In the arrow diagrams,two diagrams are drawn: one on the left representing morphisms in the category C and one on the right representing morphisms in the category D . The diagram on the left is commutative (i.e., a=Ga¯∘η ). Thus, when representing morphisms from multiple categories in arrow diagrams, multiple diagrams are generally required. As can be seen from this example, the correspondence between arrow diagrams and string diagrams is not very direct.
The main advantages of string diagrams over arrow diagrams are as follows ‡1 :
  • A diagram can convey a large amount of information in an easy-to-understand form. While, in arrow diagrams, typically, only objects and morphisms within a single category can be represented in a single diagram, it is often necessary to represent objects and morphisms in multiple categories, as well as functors and natural transformations. String diagrams can represent all of them in a single diagram.
  • Expressions involving both vertical and horizontal composition can be straightforwardly represented. Related to Advantage 1, horizontal composition is generally represented using equational forms in arrow diagrams. In contrast, both vertical and horizontal composition can be clearly represented in a string diagram. String diagrams are well-suited for representing the composition of morphisms, categories, functors, and natural transformations, revealing their structural relationships.
For a comparison of arrow diagrams and string diagrams from the perspective of a calculational approach, see the Introduction of Ref. [7].
‡1 There are also situations where arrow diagrams are preferable to string diagrams. The main disadvantages of string diagrams are as follows: (a) It is difficult to effectively represent commutative expressions when they appear frequently. (b) The style of drawing string diagrams can differ significantly among individuals.

(2) Relationship with pasting diagrams

The following is an example comparing pasting diagrams with the string diagrams:

(1.2)
In the pasting diagram,two types of arrows appear: arrows " → " representing functors and arrows " ⇒ " representing natural transformations. Also,categories C,D ,and E are represented by points; functors K:C→D,F:C→E ,and L:D→E by arrows; and a natural transformation η:F⇒L∙K (where ∙ denotes horizontal composition) by a triangle with vertices C,D ,and E having an arrow " ⇒ ". When overlaid as in Eq. (1.2),it can be seen that each arrow (in the pasting diagram) and the corresponding wire (in the string diagram) can be drawn in such a way that they are orthogonal to each other. The differences between pasting and string diagrams can be summarized as shown in Table 1.1.
Table 1.1: Differences between pasting and string diagrams.
pasting diagramsstring diagrams
categoriespoints (0-dimensional)surfaces (2-dimensional)
functorsarrows "→" (1-dimensional)wires (1-dimensional)
natural transformationssurfaces with arrows " ⇒ " (2-dimensional)blocks (0-dimensional)
Another example is
(A) pasting diagram: (B) string diagram:
(1.3)
where we represent the horizontal composition of a natural transformation γ with the vertical composition of two natural transformations α and β ,i.e., γ∙βα . Both diagrams represent vertical composition by stacking elements vertically and horizontal composition by placing them side by side. As with the previous example, it is immediately clear that the two diagrams can be overlaid.
Pasting and string diagrams are dual to each other and can be converted interchangeably. However, when it comes to discussions regarding the foundations of category theory, there are often instances where calculations involving natural transformations need to be carried out. Therefore, it is crucial to visually represent natural transformations in a clear form when performing calculations. Keeping this in mind, the main advantage of string diagrams over pasting diagrams is as follows:
  • The same type of natural transformation can be represented in the same way. In pasting diagrams, it can often be difficult to represent identical or the same type of natural transformations in the same shape. For example,consider the scenario where α=β=γ holds in Eq. (1.3). In contrast, in string diagrams, these natural transformations can always (and easily) be represented in the same shape. Therefore, when calculating natural transformations, string diagrams should be visually easier to understand. Also, thanks to this advantage, it is easy to assign a special shape to a special type of natural transformation (such as the black circle in Eq. (1.1)) and distinguish it from others.

1.2 Key aspects of this paper

The article most closely related to this paper is Ref. [7], in which it has been argued that string diagrams have utility in calculational approaches to category theory. This paper aims to demonstrate the usefulness of string diagrams for various concepts mentioned in standard textbooks on category theory, which were not extensively explored in Ref. [7]. Several key aspects of this paper include:
  • Set-valued functors: We introduce several diagrams for set-valued functors. Using these diagrams, we prove the Yoneda lemma in an intuitively understandable form (see Theorem 3.15).
  • Universal properties: We represent universal properties with simple diagrams (see Section 3.2.4). Note that this representation is similar to that of Ref. [4]. Diagrams for adjoints, (co)limits, Kan extensions, etc. are depicted as specific instances of this representation.
  • (Co)limits: We show some basic properties (e.g., any right adjoint and functor of the form C(c,−) preserve limits).
  • Kan extensions: We mainly show some basic properties of pointwise Kan extensions.
  • (Co)ends: We introduce a new diagram that visually represents (co)end-related expressions such as DC(F,G)≅∫c∈CD(Fc,Gc) in an easy-to-understand form and perform several (co)end calculations graphically.

2 Basics of string diagrams

In this section, we provide an overview of how to represent very basic concepts in category theory, such as categories, functors, and natural transformations, using string diagrams.

2.1 Categories, functors, and natural transformations

2.1.1 Categories

For morphisms f:a→b and g:b→c in a category C ,the composite of f and g ,denoted by g∘f:a→c (or simply written as gf ),is represented by the following diagram:

For two functors F,G:C→D ,a natural transformation α:F⇒G is defined as a collection of indexed morphisms α:={αa∈D(Fa,Ga)}a∈C satisfying

(2.5)
We often represent the component αa of the natural transformation α by placing α immediately to the right of the object a . When the components of a natural transformation are represented as in Eq. (2.5), Eq. (nat) can be rewritten as follows:
(2.6)
Intuitively,this equation indicates that the morphism f and the natural transformation α can be moved freely along the wires. This equation is often called the sliding rule. The right-hand side of Eq. (2.6) is sometimes denoted by α∙f ,where the operator ∙ represents the horizontal composition, which will be mentioned later.
Objects and morphisms in a category C can be regarded as functors and natural transformations from 1 to C ,respectively. For example,a functor F:1→C can be identified with an object F(∗) in C ,and a natural transformation α:F⇒G with F,G:1→C can be identified with its unique component α∗∈C(F(∗),G(∗)) . In this paper,we identify them.

2.2 Vertical and horizontal composition

2.2.1 Vertical composition

2.2.2 Horizontal composition

Since functors can be regarded as maps (for objects and morphisms), they can be composed using ordinary map composition. Specifically,for two functors F:C→D and G:D→E ,we can consider a map that maps each object a in C to the object G(Fa) and each morphism f in C to the morphism G(Ff) . This map,denoted by G∙F ,is a functor known as the horizontal composite of F and G . We write G∙F as
For a functor F:C→D ,if there exists H:D→C such that H∙F=1C and F∙H=1D ,then H is called the inverse of F and is denoted as F−1 . In this case, C and D is called isomorphic.
The horizontal composite of two natural transformations can also be defined. We write the horizontal composite of α:F⇒F′ and β:G⇒G′ (where F,F′:C→D and G,G′:D→E ) as β∙α ,which is depicted as
Specifically,it is defined as β∙α:={βF′a∘Gαa}a∈C={G′αa∘βFa}a∈C . Its each component is written as
(β∙α)a:=βF′a∘Gαa=G′αa∘βFa
where the equality follows from naturality of β . Thus,the following equation holds:
β∙α=(β∙F′)∘(G∙α)=(G′∙α)∘(β∙F)
(sld)
where β∙F′ means β∙1F′ ,and G∙α means 1G∙α . Note that the horizontal composite with the identity natural transformation is often denoted like this. This equation is also called the sliding rule. Equation (sld) intuitively means that α and β can be moved freely along the wires. Since any morphism can be regarded as a natural transformation, Eq. (2.6) can be regarded as a special case of Eq. (sld).
In what follows,when we write something like β∙α or β∘α for natural transformations α and β ,we implicitly assume that they are horizontally or vertically composable. The same applies to functors and morphisms.

2.2.3 Functor categories

For two categories C and D ,there is a functor category,denoted by DC ,whose objects are functors from C to D and whose morphisms are natural transformations. A natural transformation α:F⇒ G with F,G:C→D can be represented as a morphism in DC as follows:
In this paper,when considering the functor category DC ,it is often assumed without notice that C is small (to ensure that DC is locally small).
Example 2.8 (pre-composition with a functor): Pre-composition with a functor F:C→D is denoted by −∙F . For any category E ,this becomes a functor from ED to EC . In diagrams, −∙F corresponds to the action of placing F on the left side. Also,for a natural transformation γ:F⇒G with F,G:C→D ,pre-composition with γ can be denoted as −∙γ ,which becomes a natural transformation from −∙F to −∙G .
Example 2.9 (post-composition with a functor): Similarly to Example 2.8, post-composition with a functor F:D→E is denoted by F∙− . For any category C,F∙− becomes a functor from DC to EC . In diagrams, F∙ - corresponds to the action of placing F on the right side. Similarly,for a natural transformation γ:F⇒G with F,G:D→E , post-composition with γ is denoted by γ∙− ,which becomes a natural transformation from F∙ - to G∙ -. 2.2.4 Objects, morphisms, categories, and functors are all instances of natural transformations

We already mentioned that morphisms can be regarded as special cases of natural transformations. Here, we mention that functors, categories, and objects can also be regarded as special cases of natural transformations. This fact indicates that they can be treated uniformly as natural transformations. Specifically, we can make the following identifications:
  • Functors: Any functor F can be identified with its identity natural transformation 1F .
  • Categories: Any category C can be identified with its identity functor 1C ,and thus can be identified with the identity natural transformation 11C .
  • Objects: Any object a in a category C can be regarded as a functor from 1 to C ,and thus can be identified with the identity natural transformation 1a .
As a result, the diagrams presented in this paper can be seen as representing natural transformations that are formed through vertical and/or horizontal composition of natural transformations.

2.3 Product of categories and bifunctors

2.3.1 Product of categories

In this subsection and Section 7, we employ certain diagrams that exhibit slight variations from those previously introduced.
An object ⟨c,d⟩ (where c∈C and d∈D ) in a product category C×D is represented by the following two expressions:
⟨c,d⟩|C×D=c∧C|d∣D.
The left-hand side employs the same expression as before, while the right-hand side introduces a new expression. For convenience, we will call the latter expression "the expression for direct products". As shown on the right-hand side,we represent ⟨c,d⟩ by arranging the two arrows representing c∈C and d∈D side by side. Also,to indicate that it is a direct product,a gray dashed line is drawn between the two arrows. Note that in this expression, we represent objects with arrows instead of wires; such arrows will become useful in Section 7.

Intuitively,Condition (1) can be interpreted as allowing morphisms in C and morphisms in D to pass through α as shown in Eq. It should be easy to conceive that these conditions are equivalent.

3 The Yoneda lemma and universal properties

Adjunctions, (co)limits, and Kan extensions, which will be explained in the following sections, can be understood as certain types of universal morphisms. In this sense, a universal property, which universal morphisms possess, is a vital concept in category theory. A universal property is closely related to representability, which can be proven through the Yoneda lemma. The Yoneda lemma is "arguably the most important result in category theory" [11]. After proving the Yoneda lemma using string diagrams, we state some basic properties of universal morphisms.

3.1 The Yoneda lemma

3.1.1 Preliminaries: diagrams for morphisms

(1) Functor ◻c

Let Set denote the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms from a set X to a set Y are maps from X to Y . For each c∈C ,we can define a set-valued functor C(c,−):C→ Set that
  • maps each object a in C to the hom-set C(c,a) .
  • maps each morphism f:a→b in C to the map f∘−:C(c,a)∋g↦fg∈C(c,b) .

The Yoneda lemma asserts not only that each αX,c:AX,c→Xc is an isomorphism but also that this isomorphism is natural in both X and c .
Theorem 3.15 (the Yoneda lemma): For any object c∈C and set-valued functor X:C→ Set,define a map αX,c:SetC(◻c,X)→Xc by αX,c(τ):=τc(1c) (i.e.,as in Eq. (3.12)). Then, αX,c is an isomorphism,i.e., αX,c:SetC(◻c,X)≅Xc ,and this isomorphism is natural in X and c .
Proof. It suffices to show that (1) each αX,c is invertible and (2) α:={αX,c}X∈SetC,c∈C is a natural transformation. Furthermore,from Lemma 2.22,Condition (2) is equivalent to (2a) for each c∈ C,{αX,c}X∈SetC being a natural transformation from SetC(◻c,−) to −(c) ,and (2b) for each X∈SetC , {αX,c}c∈C being a natural transformation from SetC(◻−,X) to X . We show Conditions (1),(2a),and (2b).
(1): It suffices to show the map βX,c:Xc→SetC(◻c,X) defined as in Eq. (3.13) is the inverse of αX,c . Let us verify that βX,c is a map from Xc to SetC(◻c,X) ,i.e., βX,c(x)∈SetC(◻c,X) holds for each x∈Xc . We have for any f∈C(d,d′) ,

For any category C ,denote the functor category SetCop  as the category of presheaves and write it as C^ . Considering the dual of the Yoneda lemma yields the following corollary.
Corollary 3.21 (the Yoneda lemma): For any object c∈Cop  and presheaf X∈C^ ,define a map αX,c:C^(c◻,X)→Xc by αX,c(τ):=τc(1c) ,i.e.,
(3.22)
Then, αX,c is an isomorphism,i.e., αX,c:C^(c◻,X)≅Xc ,and this isomorphism is natural in X and c .

3.1.3 Yoneda embeddings

Let us define a functor C◻ from a category C to the category of presheaves C^ as follows:
  • It maps each object c in C to the functor c◻=C(−,c) .
  • It maps each morphism f:c→d in C to the natural transformation f◻:c◻⇒d◻ .
This functor is called the Yoneda embedding. We have for each morphism f∈C(c,d) ,

Corollary 3.24: For any category C ,the Yoneda embedding C◻ is fully faithful.
Proof. It suffices to show that for any c,d∈C and τ∈C^(c◻,d◻) ,there exists a unique f∈C(c,d) such that τ=C◻(f) (recall Eq. (2.4)). Assuming the existence of such an f ,we have
Applying αd◻,c to both sides and using βd◻,c=αd◻,c−1 ,we obtain f=αd◻,c(τ) . Therefore,there exists a unique f such that τ=C◻(f) .

3.2 Universal properties

3.2.1 Comma category c↓G

Let us arbitrarily choose an object c∈C and a functor G:D→C . The category defined as follows is called a comma category and is denoted by c↓G :
  • Its each object is a pair, ⟨x,a⟩ ,of an object x∈D and a morphism a∈C(c,Gx) .
  • Its each morphism from an object ⟨x,a⟩ to an object ⟨y,a′⟩ is a morphism f∈D(x,y) in D
56 The canonical functor P can be defined as the map of each morphism {αd,c}⟨d,c⟩∈Dop×C in SetDop×C to {{αd,c}d∈Dop}c∈C . 7 We used the fact that for any functor K:C→D ,if a morphism f in C is an isomorphism,then Kf is also an isomorphism. Additionally,if K is fully faithful,then the converse holds true.
satisfying‡8
(3.28)
  • The composite of its morphisms is the composite of morphisms in D ,and its identity morphism is the identity morphism in D .
As mentioned earlier,we identify elements x of a set X with maps {∗}∋∗↦x∈X . This identification leads to the following lemma.
Lemma 3.29: For any categories C and D ,object c∈C ,and functor G:D→C ,the comma category c↓G is equal to the comma category {∗}↓C(c,G−) .
Proof. An object in {∗}↓C(c,G−) is a pair, ⟨x,∗↦a⟩ ,of an object x∈D and a map {∗}∋∗↦ a∈C(c,Gx) . Since we identify ∗↦a with a ,this is equal to the object ⟨x,a⟩ in c↓G . This can also be seen from the following equation (note that C(c,G−)=◻c∙G ):
Also,a morphism f:⟨x,a⟩→⟨y,a′⟩ in {∗}↓C(c,G−) is a morphism f∈D(x,y) satisfying a′=Gf∘a ,and thus is a morphism in c↓G . Conversely,objects and morphisms in c↓G are contained in {∗}↓C(c,G−) . Composites of morphisms and identity morphisms are also the same. Therefore, c↓G={∗}↓C(c,G−) holds.

3.2.2 Universal morphisms

Definition 3.30 (universal morphisms): An initial object ∗a⟨u,η⟩ in a comma category c↓G is called a universal morphism from c to G . In other words, ⟨u,η⟩ with u∈D and η∈C(c,Gu) is called a universal morphism from c to G if,for any morphism a∈C(c,Gx) with any x∈D ,there exists a unique morphism a¯∈D(u,x) satisfying
(univ)
where the black circle represents η .
∗a An initial object in C is an object a in C such that for any x∈C ,there exists a unique morphism with domain a and codomain x .
Sometimes η is simply called a universal morphism. In this paper,when we mention the universal property of ⟨u,η⟩ ,we are often referring to Eq. (univ). It follows from Eq. (univ) that a and a¯ correspond one-to-one. In particular, a is η if and only if the corresponding morphism a¯ is 1u .
48 Since the domain and the codomain of each morphism in c↓G must be objects in c↓G ,strictly speaking morphisms in c↓G should be distinguished from morphisms in D . However,since it will always be clear from context which meaning is intended,we often represent morphisms in c↓G as morphisms in D . The same applies to comma categories G↓c and categories of elements mentioned later.

A universal morphism from c to G is an initial object in a comma category c↓G ,and thus is essentially unique if it exists ‡9 . More specifically,when ⟨u,η⟩ is a universal morphism from c to G ,for any universal morphism ⟨u′,η′⟩ from c to G ,there exists a unique isomorphism ψ∈D(u,u′) such that
(3.35)
where the black circle represents η ,and the diamond block represents ψ (note that in this paper, an isomorphism is often represented by a diamond block). Therefore,objects u and u′ in D are isomorphic. In particular,if η is an isomorphism,then so is η′ . Conversely,for a universal morphism ⟨u,η⟩,⟨u′,η′⟩ represented in the form of Eq. (3.35) is also a universal morphism from c to G .
For a set-valued functor X:C→ Set,the category of elements el(X) can be defined as the comma category {∗}↓X . From Lemma 3.29,we have el(C(c,G−))=c↓G .
"Essentially" means "up to isomorphism". We here used the fact that an initial object in any category is essentially unique.

3.2.3 Representable functors

For a set-valued functor X:C→ Set,if there exists an object u∈C and a natural isomorphism σ:◻u≅X ,then we call X representable and the pair ⟨u,σ⟩ a representation of X.◻u itself is obviously representable. Each component σc of σ (where c∈C ) is an invertible map from ◻u(c)=C(u,c) to Xc .
Theorem 3.36: For any categories C and D ,object c∈C ,and functor G:D→C ,we
have
a universal morphism from c to G exists ⇔C(c,G−) is representable.
Proof. We prove this using the Yoneda lemma (i.e.,Theorem 3.15). Let X:=C(c,G−) ; then, from Lemma 3.29,we have c↓G={∗}↓X . Choose an object u∈D and a natural transformation σ:◻u⇒X ,and consider αX,u(σ)=σu(1u)∈Xu=C(c,Gu) ,where αX,c is the Yoneda map (recall Eq. (3.12)). ⟨u,αX,u(σ)⟩ is a universal morphism from c to G (i.e.,an initial object in c↓G={∗}↓X) if and only if,for any object ⟨x,a⟩ in {∗}↓X ,there exists a unique a¯ satisfying
(i.e., a=σxa¯ ),where the area enclosed by the auxiliary line represents αX,u(σ) . Note that any universal morphisms from c to G is in the form of ⟨u,αX,u(σ)⟩ . Furthermore,this is equivalent to each σx with x∈D being a bijection (i.e.,an isomorphism in Set) from ◻u(x)=D(u,x) to Xx=C(c,Gx) ,and thus equivalent to σ being an isomorphism. Therefore,having a universal morphism ⟨u,αX,u(σ)⟩ from c to G is equivalent to ⟨u,σ⟩ being a representation for X .

Adjoints, (co)limits, and Kan extensions, which will be discussed in Sections 4, 5, and 6, can be seen as special cases of universal morphisms. The relationships between these concepts and universal morphisms are summarized in Table 3.1. This table also shows the diagrams mainly used in this paper. As will be shown in Subsubsection 6.3.4, adjoints and limits are also special cases of Kan extensions.

3.2.5 Comma category G↓c

We can consider an upside-down version of the comma category c↓G :
  • Its each object is a pair, ⟨x,a⟩ ,of an object x∈D and a morphism a∈C(Gx,c) .
  • Its each morphism from an object ⟨x,a⟩ to an object ⟨y,a′⟩ is a morphism f∈D(x,y) in D satisfying
(3.49)
  • The composite of its morphisms is the composite of morphisms in D ,and its identity morphism is the identity morphism in D .
This category is denoted by G↓c and is also called a comma category. Note that G↓c is not exactly the opposite of c↓G (please compare Eq. (3.28) and Eq. (3.49)).
Definition 3.50 (universal morphisms): A terminal object ∗a⟨u,ε⟩ (or simply ε ) in a comma category G↓c is called a universal morphism from G to c . In other words, ⟨u,ε⟩ with u∈D and ε∈C(Gu,c) is called a universal morphism from G to c if,for any morphism a∈C(Gx,c) with any x∈D ,there exists a unique morphism a¯∈D(x,u) satisfying

where the black circle represents ε .
∗a A terminal object in C is an object a in C such that for any x∈C ,there exists a unique morphism with domain x and codomain a .
Since terminal objects are essentially unique,universal morphisms from G to c are also essentially unique. It follows from the dual of Lemma 3.29 that G↓c is equal to the comma category (C(G−,c))op↓{∗} (where (C(G−,c))op:D→Setop and {∗}∈Setop ). Also,as the dual of Theorem 3.36, we have
a universal morphism fromGtocexists⇔C(G−,c)is representable.
(3.52)
By vertically flipping diagrams for a universal morphism from c to G ,we obtain corresponding diagrams for a universal morphism from G to c . For example,if ⟨u,σ⟩ is a representation for the functor C(G−,c) ,then any object ⟨x,a⟩ in G↓c is mapped to the following morphism a¯∈D(x,u) by σx−1 :

The category of elements of a set-valued functor Y:Cop→Set,el(Y) ,is defined as the comma category Yop ↓{∗} with {∗}∈Setop  . Then,we have el(C(G−,c))=G↓c . Some basic properties of comma categories will be discussed in Subsubsection 6.2.1.

3.3 Basic properties of universal morphisms

We show some basic properties of universal morphisms as the following three lemmas, which will be used in the following sections.
Lemma 3.53: Consider any object c∈C and functors G:D→C and G′:D′→D . Assume that there exists a universal morphism ⟨u,η⟩ from c to G ; then,the following properties hold:
(1) If there exists a universal morphism ⟨u′,η′⟩ from u to G′ ,then ⟨u′,v⟩ with v:= (G∙η′)∘η is a universal morphism from c to G∙G′ .
(2) If there exists a universal morphism ⟨u′,v⟩ from c to G∙G′ ,then there exists a universal morphism ⟨u′,η′⟩ from u to G′ satisfying v=(G∙η′)∘η .

Property (1) asserts that v:=(G∙η′)∘η , which is something corresponding to the "vertical composite of universal morphisms η and η′′ ,is a universal morphism. Conversely,Property (2) asserts that if such a universal morphism v exists, then v can be decomposed into two universal morphisms η and η′ .

4 Adjunctions

Roughly speaking, an adjunction is a concept that describes the relationship between two functors that are weakly inverse to each other. It is well known that adjunctions can be intuitively understood through the use of string diagrams. Adjunctions are also closely related to monads. String diagrams for adjunctions and monads are discussed in detail in Ref. [7]. In this paper, we briefly describe some basic properties of adjunctions in a self-contained manner. Monads are briefly covered in Subsubsection 6.3.5.

4.1 Definition of adjunctions

Definition 4.1 (adjunctions): Let us consider a pair of two functors F:C→D and G:D→C . When there is a natural isomorphism φ:D(F−,=)≅C(−,G=) ,we call ⟨F,G,φ⟩ an adjunction. Also, F is called a left adjoint to G ,and G is called a right adjoint to F . The symbol " + " is used to denote adjunctions: F⊣G means that F is a left adjoint to G .
φ={φc,d}⟨c,d⟩∈C×D is a collection of morphisms (i.e.,maps) in Set,whose each component φc,d is a bijective map from D(Fc,d) to C(c,Gd) . Naturality of φ is equivalent to satisfying

4.2 Necessary and sufficient conditions for adjunctions

(2) For each d∈D,⟨Gd,εd⟩ is a universal morphism from F to d .

4.2.2 Necessary and sufficient conditions using unit and counit

The first necessary and sufficient condition uses two natural transformations η and ε .
Theorem 4.8: Consider a pair of two functors F:C→D and G:D→C . The following are equivalent:
(1) F⊣G holds.
(2) There exist two natural transformations η:1C⇒G∙F and ε:F∙G⇒1D satisfying
(G∙ε)∘(η∙G)=1G,(ε∙F)∘(F∙η)=1F

η is called the unit of the adjunction F⊣G ,and ε is called its counit. Intuitively, ε can be interpreted as the "natural transformation obtained by rotating η by 180 degrees". Equation (snake) is often called the snake (or zigzag) equation.

Instead of calling ⟨F,G,φ⟩ an adjunction,it is also possible to call ⟨F,G,η,ε⟩ an adjunction. It follows from Eqs. (4.5) and (4.6) that φ and η ,as well as φ and ε ,can be interconverted.

4.2.3 Necessary and sufficient conditions using universal morphisms

The second necessary and sufficient condition uses universal morphisms.
Theorem 4.12: For any functor G:D→C ,the following are equivalent:
(1) G has a left adjoint.
(2) There exists a universal morphism from each c∈C to G .
Also,if Condition (1) holds,then for a left adjoint F to G and its unit η,⟨Fc,ηc⟩ is a universal morphism from c to G . On the other hand,if Condition (2) holds,then for a universal morphism ⟨dc,ηc⟩ from c to G ,there exists a unique left adjoint F to G such that Fc=dc holds and {ηc}c∈C is its unit.
By considering the dual of this theorem,it can be immediately shown that a functor F:C→ D has a right adjoint if and only if there exists a universal morphism from F to each d∈D .
Proof. (1)⇒(2) : This is obvious from Lemma 4.4.
(2)⇒(1) : For each c∈C ,let ⟨dc,ηc⟩ be a universal morphism from c to G . Considering the case where H is the identity functor in Lemma 3.56,there exists a unique functor F that maps each c∈C to Fc=dc and such that η:={ηc}c∈C is a natural transformation from 1C to G∙F . Choose the functor F in this way.
For each c∈C and d∈D ,consider the map φc,d given by Eq. (4.5). Since ⟨Fc,ηc⟩ is a universal morphism from c to G ,it follows that φc,d is invertible (see Eq. (3.38) or Eq. (3.39)). Also, it follows from Eq. (4.7) that φ:={φc,d}c∈C,d∈D is a natural isomorphism. Therefore, ⟨F,G,φ⟩ is an adjunction. Furthermore,since ηc=φc,Fc(1Fc),η is its unit.

4.3 Basic properties of adjunctions

4.3.1 Uniqueness of adjunctions

Consider an adjunction F⊣G . We show that any left adjoint to G is isomorphic to F ,which means that a left adjoint is essentially unique (see Proposition 4.13). Conversely, any functor isomorphic to F is a left adjoint to G (see Proposition 4.18). Dually,the same applies to right adjoints.

5 Limits and colimits

A (co)limit is a concept that can be used to handle various specific concepts such as products, equalizers, and pullbacks in a unified manner. Instead of dealing with these specific (co)limits, this section shows how to represent (co)limits and explains their basic properties using string diagrams.

5.1 Definition of limits and colimits

5.1.1 Cones

Definition 5.1 (cones): For an object c∈C and a functor D:J→C ,a natural transformation from ΔJc:J→C to D is called a cone from c to D ,or simply a cone to D.
As shown in Example 2.11,the functor ΔJc is the same as c∙! ,where ΔJ=−∙!:C→CJ is a diagonal functor and ! is the only functor from J to 1 . ΔJc maps all objects in J to c and all morphisms in J to 1c . The collection of all cones from c to D (i.e., CJ(ΔJc,D) ) is denoted by Cone (c,D) . In this paper,when considering cones,it is often assumed that its domain J is small (and sometimes this assumption is made implicitly).
A cone α:={αj}j∈J∈Cone(c,D) is represented by

where the functor ! is represented by a gray dotted wire. Note that we often represent a cone, which is a natural transformation,using a trapezoidal block. Naturality of α says that for any morphism h∈J(i,j) in J ,
holds.
The comma category ConeD:=ΔJ↓D is often called the category of cones to D . Let us specify ConeD (recall Subsubsection 3.2.5):
  • Its each object is a pair, ⟨c,α⟩ ,of c∈C and α∈Cone(c,D) .
  • Its each morphism with domain ⟨c,α⟩ and codomain ⟨c′,α′⟩ is a morphism f∈C(c,c′) in C such that

Roughly speaking,Cone D is a category whose objects are cones to D . Since

ConeD is equal to the category of elements of Cone(−,D) .

5.1.3 Cocones and colimits

The duals of cones and limits are called cocones and colimits, respectively. Specifically, for an object c∈C and a functor D:J→C ,a natural transformation from D to ΔJc is called a cocone from D to c or simply a cocone from D . We write Cocone(D,c) for the collection of all cocones from D to c (i.e., CJ(D,ΔJc) ). The comma category CoconeD:=D↓ΔJ is called the category of cocones from D . Also,a universal morphism from D to ΔJ (i.e.,an initial object in CoconeD ) is called a colimit of D .

In particular, d is a limit object of D if and only if ConeD has a terminal object of the form ⟨d,κ⟩ ,which is equivalent to Cone (−,D)≅d◻=C(−,d) .

5.2 Basic properties of limits and colimits

5.2.1 Limits as right adjoints to diagonal functors

From the properties of limits and adjoints, the following proposition holds.
Proposition 5.14: For a small category J and a category C ,the following are equivalent:
(1) Any functor from J to C has a limit.
(2) The diagonal functor ΔJ:C→CJ has a right adjoint.
Furthermore,if they hold,then there exists a functor lim:CJ→C that maps each functor D:J→C to one of its limit objects,and lim is a right adjoint to the diagonal functor ΔJ . Moreover,for the counit ε of the adjunction ΔJ⊣lim,εD is a limit cone of D .
Proof. (1)⇒(2) : Since each D:J→C has a limit,i.e.,a universal morphism from ΔJ to each D exists,from the dual of Theorem 4.12, ΔJ has a right adjoint.
(2)⇒(1) : Let lim be a right adjoint to ΔJ . Also,arbitrarily choose D:J→C . Then,from Lemma 4.4, ⟨limD,εD⟩ is a universal morphism from ΔJ to D ,i.e.,a limit of D .
Dually,any functor from J to C has a colimit if and only if ΔJ:C→CJ has a left adjoint.
Let us specify such a functor lim. For each D:J→C ,choose one of its limits and denote it by ⟨limD,εD⟩ . Also,for each natural transformation τ∈CJ(D,D′) ,let limτ be τ¯∈C(limD,limD′) satisfying
where the black circles are εD and εD′ . Then,for each τ∈CJ(D,D′) and τ′∈CJ(D′,D′′) , limτ′τ=(limτ′)(limτ) holds from
and the dual of Eq. (3.45). Also,lim maps the identity morphism 1D to the identity morphism 1limD ,and thus lim is a functor. When a functor lim exists,using the expression of counits introduced in Eq. (4.9),the limit cone εD can be represented by
DCJlimDCΔ|lim(ΔJ)=D|lim(ΔJ).
The counit ε of this adjunction is the collection {εD}D∈CJ . Equations (5.4) and (5.5) can be rewritten as follows:
A category C is called complete if any functor D:J→C with any small category J has a limit and cocomplete if any functor D:J→C with any small category J has a colimit.

5.2.3 Limits and colimits of functors to functor categories

The following proposition asserts that a limit of a functor from a small category J to a functor category CI can be obtained from limits of the functors evi∙D(i∈I) .
Proposition 5.19: Consider a functor D:J→CI with a small category J . Assume that, for each i∈I,Di:=evi∙D=D(−)(i) has a limit ⟨li,κi⟩ . Let us express κi as {κi,j}j∈J and let κ:={{κi,j}i∈I}j∈J . Then,there exists a unique functor L∈CI such that L(i)=li holds and that κ is a cone from L to D . Also, ⟨L,κ⟩ is a limit of D . Dually,the same holds for colimits.
Proof. Let P be the canonical functor from CIJ to CJI‡11 ,and let D−:=P∙D ; then,we have D−(i)=Di . Note that the two functors D:J→CI and D−:I→CJ are related as if the order of I and J were swapped. We prove this proposition by replacing the discussion about D with the discussion about D− .
Let κ−:={κi}i∈I ; then, κ={{κi,j}i∈I}j∈J is a natural transformation from ΔJL:J→CI to D (i.e.,a cone from L to D ) if and only if κ−={{κi,j}j∈J}i∈I is a natural transformation from ΔJ∙L:I→CJ to D− . Indeed,if κ− is a natural transformation,then
holds,and thus κ is a natural transformation. The converse also holds since κ−=P∙κ .
It follows from Lemma 3.55 that ⟨L,κ⟩ is a universal morphism from ΔJ to D if and only if ⟨L,κ−⟩ is a universal morphism from ΔJ∙ - to D− . Thus,it is sufficient to show that a functor L satisfying the conditions is uniquely determined and that ⟨L,κ−⟩ is a universal morphism from ΔJ∙ - to D− . Corollary 5.20: If any functor from a small category J to a category C has a limit,then any functor from J to CI also has a limit. The same holds for colimits.
Proof. From Proposition 5.19,for any functor D:J→CI ,since Di:=evi∙D has a limit,so does D .

5.2.4 Interactions between limits

Let us consider a bifunctor D:I×J→C ,where I and J are small categories. Let P be the canonical functor from CI×J to CIJ . Also,let one of the limit objects of P∙D:J→CI be written as limj∈J⁡D(−,j)∈CI . Note that this limit object is a functor from I to C and does not depend on j ; it may be helpful to think of j as representing something like an internal variable. Similarly,by swapping the roles of I and J ,we can define limi∈I⁡D(i,−)∈CJ . Using the same notation,let limj∈J⁡Ej denote a limit object of a functor E:J→C (i.e., limj∈J⁡Ej≅limE holds). Then,a limit object of D(i,−) can be expressed as limj∈J⁡D(i,j)∈C and a limit object of D can be expressed as lim⟨i,j⟩∈I×J⁡D(i,j) . Applying Proposition 5.19 to the functor P∙D ,if there exists a limit object limj∈J⁡D(i,j) for each i∈I ,then there exists a functor L satisfying L(i)=limj∈J⁡D(i,j) and L≅limj∈J⁡D(−,j) . Furthermore,when limj∈J⁡D(−,j) has a limit,we can write its limit object as limi∈I⁡limj∈J⁡D(i,j) .
The following proposition holds.
♯11P can be defined as the map of each morphism {{αi,j}i∈I}j∈J in CI to {{αi,j}j∈J}i∈I (see footnote ‡6 ). The canonical functor from CI×J to CIJ can be defined in a similar manner.
Proposition 5.21: Let us consider a bifunctor D:I×J→C ,where I and J are small categories. Assume that for each i∈I,D(i,−) has a limit,in which case we can define a functor limj∈J⁡D(−,j) . If either limj∈J⁡D(−,j) or D has a limit,then the other also has a limit and we have
limi∈I⁡limj∈J⁡D(i,j)≅lim⟨i,j⟩∈I×J⁡D(i,j).
(5.22)
Proof. Let P be the canonical functor from CI×J to CIJ . From Proposition 5.19, P∙D has a limit. Let this limit be denoted as ⟨limj∈J⁡D(−,j),κ⟩ . From Lemma 3.55,we have
⟨lim⟨i,j⟩∈I×J⁡D(i,j),v′⟩ is a limit of D (i.e.,a universal morphism from ΔI×J to D )

Corollary 5.24: Consider any category C and small categories I and J . Assume that any functor from I to C and functor from J to C have limits. Then,a functor D:I×J→C has a limit and satisfies
limi∈I⁡limj∈J⁡D(i,j)≅lim⟨i,j⟩∈I×J⁡D(i,j)≅limj∈J⁡limi∈I⁡D(i,j).
Proof. The first isomorphism is obvious from Proposition 5.21. Swapping I and J yields the second isomorphism.

6 Kan extensions

Kan extensions are concepts that can unify the treatment of adjoints and limits from different perspectives. It has been pointed out that "The notion of Kan extensions subsumes all the other fundamental concepts of category theory" [6]. String diagrams are also useful when investigating the properties of Kan extensions. After discussing general Kan extensions, we explain the properties of pointwise Kan extensions, which are often recognized as important Kan extensions.

6.1 Definition of Kan extensions

Definition 6.1 (Kan extensions): Consider two functors K:C→D and F:C→E . A universal morphism ⟨L,η⟩ from F to −∙K:ED→EC is called a left Kan extension of F along K.η is also called its unit. In other words, ⟨L,η⟩ is called a left Kan extension of F along K if for any H:D→E and σ:F⇒H∙K ,there exists a unique σ¯:L⇒H satisfying

As the dual to a left Kan extension,a universal morphism ⟨R,ε⟩ from −∙K to F is called a right Kan extension of F along K.ε is also called its counit. In other words, ⟨R,ε⟩ is called a right Kan extension of F along K if for any H:D→E and σ:H∙K⇒F ,there exists a unique σ¯:H⇒R satisfying
(6.3)
where the blue circle is the counit ε .
We sometimes simply refer to L as a left Kan extension and R as a right Kan extension. We often write L as LanKF and R as RanKF . Diagrams for right Kan extensions correspond to the "upside-down" version of diagrams for left Kan extensions. In what follows, we often only consider the properties of left Kan extensions, but by flipping diagrams upside-down, we can immediately obtain the properties of right Kan extensions.

The same applies to right Kan extensions.
Left Kan extensions are essentially unique if they exist, and so are right Kan extensions. Here, we specifically discuss the case of left Kan extensions. 6.2.1 Preliminaries: Basic properties of comma categories

6.2.2 Pointwise Kan extensions

Assume that there exists a left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ of a functor F:C→E along a functor K:C→D . To explicitly determine LanKF and η ,let us consider the composite of η and the canonical natural transformation θd for K↓d for each d∈D . Specifically,we define μd as

Unfortunately,the existence of a left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ does not guarantee that F∙Pd has a colimit for each d∈D . However,conversely,if these colimits exist,then it can be shown that
  • There exists a left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ satisfying Eq. (6.15) (see Theorem 6.20).
  • For any left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ ,each μd defined by Eq. (6.15) is a colimit cocone of F∙Pd (see Corollary 6.25).
Therefore,let us call a left Kan extension pointwise if F∙Pd has a colimit for each d∈D . Explicitly, it is defined as follows:
Definition 6.17 (pointwise Kan extensions): Consider two functors K:C→D and F:C→E . A left Kan extension of F along K is called pointwise if F∙Pd has a colimit for each d∈D . Dually,a right Kan extension of F along K is called pointwise if F∙Pd has a limit for each d∈D .
If a pointwise left Kan extension LanKF exists,then any left Kan extension of F along K is pointwise (the same applies to right Kan extensions). This is because whether or not F∙Pd has a colimit does not depend on the choice of the left Kan extension. As will gradually become clear, several useful properties hold if a Kan extension is pointwise.

6.3 Basic properties of Kan extensions

6.3.1 Functors preserving Kan extensions

As with the preservation of limits, we can consider the preservation of Kan extensions as follows. Consider a functor S:E→F . When there exists a left Kan extension of F:C→E along K:C→D ,denoted by ⟨LanKF,η⟩ ,we say that S preserves the left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ if ⟨S∙LanKF,S∙η⟩ is a left Kan extension of S∙F along K . Also,we call S preserving any left Kan extension if it preserves the left Kan extensions of any functor F:C→E along any functor K:C→D ,where C and D are arbitrary. The preservation of right Kan extensions is defined as its dual.
Assume that there exists a left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ of F along K and that S preserves this Kan extension; then,for any natural transformation σ:S∙F⇒H∙K (where H:D→F is arbitrary),there exists a unique σ¯:S∙LanKF⇒H satisfying
(6.33)
where the blue circle represents η . This equation corresponds to Eqs. (6.2) and (6.4). The preservation of the left Kan extension ⟨LanKF,η⟩ by S can be represented by
where for any arbitrarily chosen left Kan extension ⟨LanK(S∙F),η′⟩ of S∙F along K,η′ is represented by the blue ellipse on the right-hand side. The diamond block represents the isomorphism S∙LanKF≅LanK(S∙F) .
The following proposition holds:
Proposition 6.34: Any left adjoint preserves any left Kan extension. Dually, any right adjoint preserves any right Kan extension.
Since colimits are left Kan extensions and limits are right Kan extensions as mentioned in Example 6.6, this proposition can be regarded as a generalization of Theorem 5.16.
Proof. We show that for any adjunction S⊣T:E→F,S preserves any left Kan extension, denoted by ⟨LanKF,η⟩ ,of a functor F:C→E along a functor K:C→D . We have for any natural transformation σ:S∙F⇒H∙K (where H:D→F is arbitrary),

(6.2)). The blue circle represents η . In the last equality,we set the transpose of τ¯ to τ . Since τ is uniquely determined from σ,⟨S∙LanKF,S∙η⟩ is a left Kan extension of S∙F along K .

6.3.2 Conditions for having a pointwise Kan extension

Corollary 6.35: Consider two functors K:C→D and F:C→E ,where C is a small category. If E is cocomplete,then a pointwise left Kan extension of F along K exists. Dually,if E is complete,then a pointwise right Kan extension of F along K exists.
Proof. Since C is small,for any d∈D ,the comma category K↓d is small. Thus,if E is cocomplete,then for each d∈D ,a colimit of F∙Pd exists. Therefore,a pointwise left Kan extension of F along K obviously exists from Theorem 6.20.
Proposition 6.36: Consider three functors K:C→D,F:C→E ,and L:D→E . The
following conditions are equivalent:
(1) L is a pointwise left Kan extension of F along K .
(2) L is a left Kan extension of F along K ,and for any e∈E,e◻:E→Setop  preserves the left Kan extension L .

A left (or right) Kan extension L of F:C→E along K:C→D is called absolute if any functor H:E→F (where F is arbitrary) preserves L . Any absolute Kan extension is pointwise since this condition is stronger than Condition (2) of Proposition 6.36.

6.3.4 Relationship with adjoints

We have already mentioned in Example 6.39 that limits and colimits are special cases of pointwise Kan extensions. Here, we show that left and right adjoints are also special cases of pointwise Kan extensions. In particular, they are absolute Kan extensions. 7 (Co)ends and weighted (co)limits

In this section, we mainly discuss (co)ends and weighted (co)limits, which can be viewed as generalizations of (co)limits in a certain sense. These concepts are also closely related to pointwise Kan extensions. We use string diagrams to illustrate some of the relationships between (co)limits, pointwise Kan extensions, (co)ends, and weighted (co)limits. String diagrams for (co)ends are also described in Refs. [3,12,13] and references cited therein. We propose a new representation method that allows us to perform (co)end calculations intuitively.

7.1 Diagrams for direct products

In this section, we mainly use the "expression for direct products" (recall Subsubsection 2.3.1). In this expression,for a morphism f∈C(a,b) and a functor F:C→D,Ff is represented by the right-hand side of the following diagram:
For a morphism g∈Cop(b,a)=C(a,b) and a contravariant functor G:Cop→D ,in the expression for direct products,we represent Gg by the right-hand side of the following diagram:
In the expression for direct products, we represent objects and morphisms in the opposite category Cop  as "upside-down" versions of the corresponding objects and morphisms in C . For convenience,we label the category Cop  with " C " in such expressions,but instead represent objects with downward-pointing arrows; we can distinguish whether it represents C or Cop from the direction of the arrows. For a blue arrow representing a functor F:C→D ,its dual F:Cop→Dop can be represented by vertically flipping the direction of the arrow.
Also, products are represented by placing elements side by side. For example, the product ⟨f,g⟩∈mor(Cop×C) of f∈Cop(a,b) and g∈C(c,d) is represented by
(7.1)
The gray dashed line representing the product " × " can be omitted.
In summary, compared to the main expression, the expression for direct products has the following main differences:
(1) It represents products (and tensor products, as will be shown in Subsection 7.4) by placing elements side by side.
(2) It represents applying a functor by drawing two parallel arrows to the left and right.
(3) It represents objects and functors with upward or downward arrows instead of wires. A category C and its opposite category Cop  are distinguished by the direction of arrows.
We represent C(a,b) as
where the dotted arrow is a singleton set {∗}∈ Set. Note that in this diagram, C(a,b) is represented as a morphism from {∗} to C(a,b) . As shown on the right-hand side,dotted arrows representing {∗} are often omitted. The dark gray rectangle represents the hom-functor C(−,=):Cop×C→ Set, with aop ∈Cop  represented as an upside-down version of a∈C with a downward arrow. For a contravariant functor F:Cop→D,D(Fc,d) can be represented by

Supplement: This representation enables us to easily depict properties, such as "returning to its original state after undergoing two upside-down flips". Therefore, this representation will frequently prove valuable in subsequent discussions.

It could be more comprehensible if you think of it this way: C(a,−) can be viewed as an element of SetC ,as shown on the left side of the diagram,and when viewed as a functor from C to Set ,it is represented as shown on the right side.

7.2 Definition of (co)ends

7.2.1 Wedges and ends

Definition 7.2 (wedges): For an object c∈C and a bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C ,a collection of morphisms α:={αj:c→D(j,j)}j∈J in C is called a wedge from c to D ,or simply a wedge to D ,if it satisfies
D(i,h)∘αi=D(h,j)∘αj
for any morphism h∈J(i,j) . In diagrams,we represent the component αj of the wedge α as
where a dotted semicircle is drawn inside the block.
We write Wedge (c,D) for the collection of all wedges from c to D . For a bifunctor D:Jop × J→C ,let us consider the following category:
  • Its each object is a pair, ⟨c,α⟩ ,of c∈C and α∈Wedge(c,D) .
  • Its each morphism from an object ⟨c,α⟩ to an object ⟨c′,α′⟩ is a morphism f∈C(c,c′) in C that satisfies αj=αj′f for all j∈J .
  • The composite of its morphisms is the composite of morphisms in C ,and its identity morphism is the identity morphism in C .
This category is called the category of wedges to D ,and we write Wedge D . Roughly speaking, WedgeD is a category whose objects are wedges to D .
Definition 7.3 (ends): Consider a bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C . A terminal object ⟨d,κ⟩ in WedgeD is called an end of D . In other words,a pair, ⟨d,κ⟩ ,of an object d∈C and a wedge κ∈Wedge(d,D) is called an end of D if for any wedge α∈Wedge(c,D) (where c∈C is also arbitrary),there exists a unique morphism α¯∈C(c,d) satisfying
αj=κjα¯
Sometimes d is simply called an end.
The end d is often written as ∫j∈JD(j,j) . From the above universal property, d∈D is an end of D if and only if
C(−,d)≅Wedge(−,D)
holds,where Wedge(−,D):Cop → Set is a presheaf (in the case where Wedge(c,D) is a set for each c∈C ) defined as follows:
  • It maps each object c in Cop  to Wedge (c,D) .
  • It maps each morphism f∈Cop(b,a)=C(a,b) to the map (i.e.,the morphism in Set) Wedge(b,D)∋{αj}j∈J↦{αjf}j∈J∈Wedge(a,D).
Example 7.4 (limits are ends): For a functor D′:J→C ,let D:Jop ×J→C be the bifunctor defined by D(f,g):=D′(g)(f∈morJop ,g∈morJ) . Then,for any c∈C ,a cone from c to D′ is equivalent to a wedge from c to D ,i.e., Cone(c,D′)=Wedge(c,D) holds. We can also readily obtain ConeD′=WedgeD . Furthermore,a limit of D′ is equivalent to an end of D since the former is a terminal object in ConeD′ while the latter is a terminal object in WedgeD .

7.2.2 Cowedges and coends

Cowedges and coends can be defined as the duals of wedges and ends.
Definition 7.5 (cowedges): For an object c∈C and a bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C ,a collection of morphisms α:={αj:D(j,j)→c}j∈J in C is called a cowedge from D to c , or simply a cowedge from D ,if it satisfies
αi∘D(i,h)=αj∘D(h,j)
for any morphism h∈J(j,i) . In diagrams,we represent the component αj of the cowedge α as
We write Cowedge(D,c) for the collection of all cowedges from D to c . Also,the category defined as follows is called the category of cowedges from D ,and we write CowedgeD :
  • Its each object is a pair, ⟨c,α⟩ ,of c∈C and α∈Cowedge(D,c) .
  • Its each morphism from an object ⟨c,α⟩ to an object ⟨c′,α′⟩ is a morphism f∈C(c,c′) in C that satisfies αj′=fαj for all j∈J .
  • The composite of its morphisms is the composite of morphisms in C ,and its identity morphism is the identity morphism in C .
Definition 7.6 (coends): Consider a bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C . An initial object ⟨d,κ⟩ in Cowedge D is called a coend of D . In other words,a pair, ⟨d,κ⟩ ,of an object d∈C and a cowedge κ∈Cowedge(D,d) is called a coend of D if for any cowedge α∈Cowedge(D,c)
(where c∈C is also arbitrary),there exists a unique morphism α¯∈C(d,c) satisfying
αj=α¯κj
Sometimes d is simply called a coend.
The coend d is often written as ∫j∈JD(j,j) . From the above universal property, d∈D is a coend of D if and only if
C(d,−)≅Cowedge(D,−)
holds,where Cowedge(D,−):C→ Set is a functor (in the case where Cowedge(D,c) is a set for each c∈C ) defined similarly to Wedge (−,D) .
Example 7.7 (colimits are coends): Considering the dual of Example 7.4, we can see that any cocone is a cowedge and any colimit is a coend.

7.2.3 Diagrams for ends

For a bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C ,we represent its end and coend as
Note that they are objects in C that are independent of j . The black horizontal lines in the diagrams represent " ∫j∈J " and " ∫j∈J ". As shown on their right-hand sides,the arrows below the horizontal line representing " ∫j∈J " and above the horizontal line representing " ∫j∈J, ,are often omitted. Also,the label " j " in these diagrams is often omitted.
Consider a functor D:Jop ×J×D→C . For any d∈D ,we can define a functor D(−,=,d):Jop ×J→C (recall Example 2.20). We represent an end of this functor as
∫j∈JD(j,j,d)diagramdiagram c|∂|j|j↑|d|D|D.
Other (co)ends,such as ∫j∈JD(j,j,d) or ∫j∈JE(j,d,j,d′) ,can also be considered similarly.

7.3 Basic properties of (co)ends

7.3.1 Properties of (co)ends as (co)limits

It is known that ends are special cases of limits, and coends are special cases of colimits (e.g., [6]). Therefore, properties that hold for (co)limits hold for (co)ends. Also, concepts related to (co)limits, such as their preservation, can be applied directly to (co)ends. Here, we provide several examples.
For each c∈C,◻c=C(c,−) preserves any limit (recall Theorem 5.17),so it preserves any end. That is,for any c∈C and bifunctor D:Jop ×J→C ,
(7.8)
holds. Note that the area enclosed by the auxiliary line represents the bifunctor C(c,D(−,=)) . Since an end is a limit,this isomorphism is natural in c and D . In Eq. (7.8),there are short horizontal lines attached to arrows representing c and D ,which indicate that the isomorphism is natural in c and D . In what follows,we use such expressions to represent naturality. Intuitively, this diagram can be interpreted as allowing the horizontal solid line representing " ∫j∈J " to freely pass through the dark gray rectangle representing the hom-functor C(−,=) .
As the dual of Eq. (7.8), c◻=C(−,c) preserves any colimit (recall Corollary 5.18),so it preserves any coend. That is,
C(∫j∈JD(j,j),c)≅∫j∈JC(D(j,j),c)
(7.9)
holds ♯13 . Note that by representing the coend ∫j∈JD(j,j) as an "upside-down" version,we intuitively show how a coend is transformed into an end.
Also,if a category C is complete,then for any small category J and functor D:Iop ×I× Jop ×J→C
∫i∈I∫j∈JD(i,i,j,j)≅∫j∈J∫i∈ID(i,i,j,j)
(7.10)
holds,where DI:=∫j∈JD(−,=,j,j) and DJ:=∫i∈ID(i,i,−,=) . Note that the gray dashed lines in the horizontal direction are natural isomorphisms. This isomorphism justifies that both the left-and right-hand sides of Eq. (7.10) are represented by

7.4 (Co)tensor products

7.4.1 Definition of (co)tensor products

As a preliminary,we introduce (co)tensor products. For a set X and an object c∈C ,if there exists an object,denoted by X⊗c ,in C such that
C(X⊗c,c′)≅Set(X,C(c,c′))
(7.15)
is natural in c′ ,then X⊗c is called a tensor product (or copower) of X and c . Also,if there exists a functor ⊗: Set ×C→C that maps ⟨X,c⟩∈ Set ×C to X⊗c∈C such that Eq. (7.15) is natural in X,c,c′ ,then ⊗ is called the tensor product. We have for any X∈Set and c∈C,X⊗c≅∐x∈X⁡c (where II is the coproduct). Therefore,if C is cocomplete,then C has any tensor product. In particular,for C= Set, X⊗c≅X×c holds. If C has any tensor product,then for each c∈C , C(c,−) has a left adjoint −⊗c .
The dual of a tensor product can also be considered. Specifically,for a set X and an object c′∈C ,if there exists an object,denoted by X⋔c′ ,in C such that
C(c,X⋔c′)≅Set(X,C(c,c′))
(7.16)
is natural in c ,then X⋔c′ is called a cotensor product (or power) of X and c′ . Also,if there exists a functor ⋔:Setop ×C→C that maps ⟨X,c′⟩∈Setop ×C to X⋔c′∈C such that Eq. (7.16) is natural in X,c,c′ ,then ⋔ is called the cotensor product. We have for any X∈ Set and a∈C , X⋔a≅∏x∈X⁡a (where Π is the direct product). Therefore,if C is complete,then C has any cotensor product. In particular,for C=Set,X⋔a≅aX:=Set(X,a) holds.
Consider the tensor product ⊗: Set ×C→C and the cotensor product ⋔:Setop ×C→C . Like direct products (see Eq. (7.1)), we represent (co)tensor products by placing elements side by side. However,unlike direct products,we do not insert dashed lines. Specifically,for X∈Set and c∈C ,we represent X⊗c and X⋔c by
Note that X is an object in Set,not in C . If C has any tensor product and cotensor product,then from Eqs. (7.15) and (7.16), there exists an isomorphism
C(X⊗c,c′)≅Set(X,C(c,c′))≅C(c,X∩c′)
(7.17)
that is natural in X∈ Set and c,c′∈C . In particular,when C= Set,the first isomorphism of Eq. (7.17) is equivalent to
(7.18)

7.4.2 Topics related to (co)tensor products

(1) Expressions of pointwise Kan extensions by (co)tensor products
Proposition 7.19: Consider two functors K:C→D and F:C→E ,where C is small. If E is cocomplete,then a pointwise left Kan extension LanKF exists and satisfies
LanKF≅∫c∈CD(Kc,−)⊗Fc
(7.20)
Dually,if E is complete,then a pointwise right Kan extension RanKF exists and satisfies
RanKF≅∫c∈CD(−,Kc)⋔Fc diagram

that is natural in F and H . Thus,from Eq. (6.8),Eq. (7.20) holds.
Note that Proposition 6.36 asserts that if a functor L:D→E is a pointwise left Kan extension of F along K ,then the isomorphism
E(Ld,e)≅C^(D(K−,d),E(F−,e))
(7.21)
is natural in d and e . It can be seen that Eq. (7.21) is obtained by applying E(−(d),e) to Eq. (7.20).

(2) The co-Yoneda lemma

Corollary 7.22 (the co-Yoneda lemma): We have for objects c,d in a small category C and a functor F:C→ Set,
∫c∈CC(c,d)×Fc≅Fd≅∫c∈CFc×C(c,d)
(7.23)
Proof. It is sufficient to show the first isomorphism since the right-hand side is simply a rearrangement of the direct product on the left-hand side. This can be easily seen by considering the case of D=C,E= Set,and K=1C in Proposition 7.19. Indeed,since Set is cocomplete, Lan1CF exists and satisfies Eq. (7.20). Thus,from Lan1C≅1SetC ,we obtain Eq. (7.23).
Equation (7.23) can be rewritten as
∫c∈C◻c×Fc≅F≅∫c∈CFc×◻c.
Dually, the following corollary holds.

(4) Adjunctions between the category of presheaves

It can be shown that for a small category C ,any adjunction F⊣G:C^→D can be expressed using a certain Kan extension (see Proposition 7.34), and the converse also holds (see Proposition 7.33).
Proposition 7.33: Consider a functor K:C→D ,where C is small. If a pointwise left Kan extension F:=LanC◻K:C^→D exists,then F⊣LanKC◻ holds.
‡18 This can be shown in the same way as footnote ‡15 using the fact that Set is complete.
419 If an exponential object GF exists,then there must exist an isomorphism GF(c)≅C^(c◻,GF)≅C^(c◻×F,G) that is natural in c ,where the first isomorphism is due to the Yoneda lemma (see Corollary 3.21). Therefore, GF must be defined to satisfy Eq. (7.32).

∫c∈CSet(Hc,GFc)≅(7.32)∫c∈CSet(Hc,C^(c◻×F,G))≅(7.17)∫c∈CC^(Hc⊗(c◻×F),G)

Proposition 7.34: Consider an adjunction F⊣G:C^→D ,where C is small. There exists a functor K:C→D satisfying F≅LanC◻K and G≅LanKC◻ .
Intuitively,the functor K can be said to have information about both F and G .
Proof. Let K:=F∙C◻ . From LanC◻C◻≅1C^ (recall Corollary 7.29) and the fact that the left adjoint F preserves any left Kan extension (recall Proposition 6.34),we obtain
F≅F∙LanC◻C◻≅LanC◻(F∙C◻)≅LanC◻K.
For each X∈C^ ,let PX be the forgetful functor from C◻↓X to C ; then, C◻∙PX:C◻↓X→C^ has a colimit since C^ is cocomplete. Thus, F∙C◻∙PX=K∙PX also has a colimit since the left adjoint F preserves any colimit (recall Theorem 5.16). Therefore,the Kan extension F≅LanC◻K is pointwise,and thus from Proposition 7.33, LanKC◻ is a right adjoint to F . Since right adjoints are essentially unique,we have G≅LanKC◻ .

7.5 Weighted (co)limits

Weighted (co)limits can be considered as generalizations of (co)limits and (co)ends.

7.5.1 Definition of weighted (co)limits

Definition 7.35 (weighted (co)limits): Arbitrarily choose two functors W:C→ Set and F:C→E . An object,denoted by limW⁡F ,in E is called a limit of F weighted by W if the isomorphism
E(e,limW⁡F)≅SetC(W,E(e,F−))
(7.36)
is natural in e∈E . Dually,arbitrarily choose a presheaf W′:Cop → Set. An object, denoted by colimW′F ,in E is called a colimit of F weighted by W′ if the isomorphism
E(colimW′F,e)≅C^(W′,E(F−,e))
is natural in e∈E .
‡21 In mathematical notation,
D(FX,d)≅(7.21)C^(C^(C◻−,X),D(K−,d))≅(7.14)C^(X,D(K−,d))≅(7.28)C^(X,Gd).
Example 7.37: A limit of F is a limit of F weighted by ΔC{∗} ,where {∗} is a singleton set. Indeed, we have
E(e,limF)≅Cone(e,F)≅Cone({∗},E(e,F−))≅SetC(ΔC{∗},E(e,F−)),
where the first and second isomorphisms follow from Eqs. (5.9) and (5.12), respectively. Dually,a colimit of F is a colimit of F weighted by ΔCop {∗} .
In particular,when E= Set,we have
limWF≅SetC(W,F)
(7.38)
Indeed,since we have for any X∈Set‡22 ,
we obtain Eq. (7.38) from Eq. (7.36).
